conversation.content: I just converted all my preferred shares to common stock in the startup.
Oh really, so you gave up, um, your liquidation preference? That's [jealous] quite the vote of confidence, but, you know, what made you think that was, actually, the smart move here?
The board said it would align my interests better with other shareholders.
The board told you that? Let me ask you something: did they explain what happens to your voting rights when the next funding round dilutes everyone's common stock by forty percent?
Wait, they said dilution [speeding up] wouldn't be that bad since we're growing fast.
Growing fast doesn't protect you from dilution. Quick question: do you know what anti-dilution provisions you had with your preferred shares that you just gave up?
Anti-dilution provisions?
Yeah, I mean, [empathetically] most preferred stock comes with, well, weighted-average anti-dilution protection that, basically, shields you from getting crushed when they raise at a lower valuation.
[quickly] But, um, they said common stock was, you know, simpler and that, er, employees prefer it.
Employees get common stock because, hmm, they have no choice, but here's the thing, you actually had preferred shares which, honestly, are objectively better in almost every scenario.
I thought, well, common stock meant I'd make more if, sort of, we hit it big since there's no, uh, participation cap.

Did your preferred shares have a participation cap? Because most modern preferred stock is participating preferred, meaning you get both your preference AND participate pro-rata in the remaining proceeds.
Nobody, actually, explained it that way, I guess, during the, um, conversion discussion.
Of course they didn't explain it. Let me test your understanding: what happens if the company sells for less than the total amount raised from investors?
Everyone gets paid proportionally?
Wrong! The preferred shareholders, er, get paid first, [loudly] which you were until yesterday, and common stockholders, basically, get whatever scraps are left, if anything!
[very loudly] So I essentially just moved myself, you know, to the back of the line when, um, it comes to getting paid out?
Exactly! And here's another test: if the board, well, issues new shares to themselves as, uh, bonuses, whose ownership percentage gets diluted more, I mean, proportionally?
Common stockholders get diluted more?

Bingo! Common stockholders always, hmm, take the hit first, and honestly, by converting your preferred shares, you basically just volunteered to be, you know, first in line for every downside scenario.
